sort of software growing your skills and there are kind of two different sort of questions that a lot of people
find themselves in when they go on this journey one of them is i really want to be promoted i want a
new challenge i want to have a growth opportunity i want more responsibility and this is definitely one of the other paths
the second path is when other people in your sort of organization or your business look at
you and perhaps go you know you're ready for a stretch opportunity you may not think you're ready but we think that you're ready to
be promoted and we'd like you to try out this role as a tech lead so a lot of people think ah now i have
this role i am a tech lead people think that this is a step up in the ladder
and i really want you to not think about that so this is the sort of wrong mental model to approach this
and we'll come back to this idea but let's say that you have this new role and we've got this role represented by a
little badge uh you've now sort of transitioned from being just a developer perhaps to now being a tech lead
what do you do differently this is the ultimate question now a lot of the time people assume that you
know what to do because uh they assume you understand what the scope of this role is but the challenge that a lot of people
have when they find themselves in this role for the first time is that it's different in every team and it's different in every organization
and so the expectations are very very different so the first lesson uh is really that
recognizing that the tech lead role is not a promotion it's a role change
and therefore the things that you do the activities that you take care of and the responsibilities you need to be accountable for
are very different from being a developer it's not just simply more of that which is what a lot of people fall into
so let's go back to this idea of this role as a promotion now you know if you think

impact of that role now for a lot of people uh in software you typically start off being maybe a
junior software engineer as you get more experience you become more independent you can sort of build

some small micro services you become a bit more of a senior software engineer now a lot of people have this mental
model the tech lead is simply a evolution of this which is really more of what a senior software engineer does
but this is the false understanding of what this role is now the reason for this is uh you know
there's often a talk about these different development tracks in a lot of organizations so in one sort of organization they
might talk about the individual contributor track and this is typically what you think of as a software engineer
and you have kind of like a management track which is perhaps what you think of classically around perhaps entering
managers i like to describe evolution as a ternary track so a trident model of
career development and the reason for this is each of these different sort of paths has a different scope and
different responsibilities so we have a technical leadership path an individual contributor path and a management path now if we think
about sort of the purito principle 80 of your time 70 to 80 anytime what do you do for most of it
for an individual uh contributor you're spending most of your time working by yourself so executing or
doing right so this is what a lot of developers think about which and they say i want to be coding i want to write code so some of
the activities that somebody who is an individual contributor might be doing is designing software they might be testing
and validating that their software is working and of course from a software development perspective actually building
software so that takes up a majority of their time if you're in the management track i
often talk about good managers spend a lot of their time managing the system in which people are
working so they're not necessarily managing individuals but managing the work environment that needs uh sort
of taken care of in order to get things done so in a lot of organizations this might be uh sort of planning
communication with other teams coordinating it might be about supporting your team helping unblock the things your team
needs in order to get things done think about environments that you're waiting for or a dependency from another team it's
often about sort of budgeting as well in terms of trying to make sure that budgets sort of plan out uh in terms of the the sort of normal uh
sort of uh processes but the technical leader track if i think about sort of the majority of
their time they spend a lot of their time leading technical topics and what do i mean by this
some of the activities here are about aligning a team so one of the the common activities a technical leader
might need to take up is trying to get agreement within the team about perhaps which direction
they're actually heading so be it you know react versus angular or vue.js making sure that there's agreement and
alignment across that team perhaps it's about setting a technical vision about where the team needs to get to
maybe you're going on that journey from monolith to micro services and that technical vision is also
mapping out how you're going to actually get there perhaps it's making sure that there's enough sort of management around
technical debt so convincing product owners that now is the time to invest in the right level of
that and obviously trying to manage technical risks around trying to make sure that the software that you're building
is reliable scales and will meet the quality that is needed for
that particular domain that you're actually building software for and obviously knowledge sharing about making sure that there's
no uh sort of silos of knowledge so this takes up a lot of time
and you'll notice a lot of these activities aren't necessarily about them writing code as much as a individual
developer and so this is a fundamentally different skill set so a top tip for you going on this
journey or thinking about this is recognizing what got you here won't get you there
the skills you developed as a as a developer won't necessarily prepare you effectively to take care of
all the different tasks that you need to take care of if you're going to be an effective tech lead
so we'll look to the archetypical story about people finding themselves suddenly in this role and not realizing what they have to do
is actually quite different let's go into a little bit more depth about what i mean by a tech lead
so the tech lead role i think is a software engineer that is responsible for leading a development team and also
responsible for the quality of its technical deliverables so unlike a perhaps product manager who
is responsible perhaps for the product roadmap and priorities in terms of what you
focus on for customers it technically needs to be a lot more inward focused to make sure that the
system that you're building and that everyone is contributing to can continue to be evolved over time so
that's really what i mean about the the quality of the technical deliverables but also you don't really have a team if
people aren't working well together so you can have a group of individuals each writing their own sort of code but
you don't really have a strong team if they're not really working well together and that really requires a lot of stewardship which is
what this tech lead role uh tech lead role is responsible for
in terms of the overlap of skills these is this is the mental model i encourage you to adopt of a good
balance between three major areas so one of these areas is naturally around development right
so a tech lead can't be effective unless they understand the choices and the technology that
their team is using so you can't lead technical topics if you don't have that background but it
doesn't mean that you need to be the uber expert in every area that will be impossible
because you can't just uh be an expert in every single area um and so this tech lead role needs a
balance of enough development skills to be able to lead technical topics and and have respect from the team but they
also need a good balance of architecture skills and leadership skills so architecture skills in terms of not
just writing about code but really thinking about the whole environment and building systems that work well with
each other which includes people and process in your organization be it your people who operate the software or
people who are you know customer services to make sure that they can use the software and support customers using that
software and of course a key element of a tech lead is that leadership skill area of really
making sure that you build a strong team around making sure that there is a common agreed decision
to make sure that everyone is moving towards that same area and so a tech lead isn't going to be an expert in
one of these areas what they need is enough expertise in all of these areas
and a balance and that's a really key message so lesson two uh is the tech lead role
requires effective leadership skills and you may not have been given the support in your organization to build those
skills a good mental model i like to think of is let's say that you're playing an rpg
a role playing game what's very typical in an rpg is you make uh you gain experience and you can
allocate experience points to different traits and in a game you might choose a
specialist of some sort but from a tech lead perspective what's really key is you need to be
well-rounded so you can't just be single aspect focused you really have to have a good balance
and so a lot of the things that you'd be gaining experience points in will naturally be development skills as a developer and
perhaps you've built a little bit of systems or you've had more responsibilities so you've built some architecture skill
but a technique needs to have a broader set of experience around that similarly you may have had some informal
experience leading perhaps in your own sort of social sort of world
or in many opportunities but you may not have built enough leadership skills or experience to be comfortable with that
which is essential for this role and so what you have here is an imbalance in where your skills
have been allocated and to be effective you need to readdress that balance
so what this means is if you're going on this journey to become an effective tech lead you focus probably most of your
personal development on this development circle and this is fantastic that you'll hear in this talk because the key message for
you is to make sure that you start to focus on areas which you've probably not focused on in the past and this is
really around both leadership skills and architecture skills when i think about leadership you know one of the
sort of good mental models i have is when you have a team of individuals that are working in their own choice in their own
directions you if you add up their sort of vectors what you'll end up with is a sort of maybe increase but a lot of
people will be working against each other as individuals and so a good leader well this is what
effective ineffective leadership looks like a good leader is thinking about making sure that you're aligning people as much
as possible and so this is really about that decision making around making sure that there's a clear technical vision to make
sure everyone's moving in the same direction so that when you add up all people's efforts they're not sort of
undoing each other's work or fighting against each other but the team moves a lot further overall
now what does this look like for a tech lead this is really thinking as if your code base was
written by a single person now it'll never look exactly like it was written by a single person
but it's a nice simple test you know can you open up parts of the code base and you can tell
who wrote that part of the code base if you can tell then you're probably leading a group of people but not really leading a team
if you're leading a team then what you should have is an agreed standard or agreement with your team about which
patterns that you use which code styles do you choose and how do you
sort of approach the most common problems do you have four persistence frameworks do you have three different ways you
throw exceptions or errors and handle them each of these require an agreement with
the team which is a key part of technical leadership so think about this as a simple way to say
are you doing a good job by thinking about how well your code base looks uh overall um
from each person now a common question that i get from a lot of people is you
know you have this person that isn't coding as much as a developer but they still need to be you know
knowing the technology what's a good amount of time that they spend with code so my rule of thumb here is really a
sort of 30 percent rule or at least a minimum of 30 percent of time with a team now i say this because
you know you can't have zero percent of time without understanding how that system is evolving you know if you have a big team
your code is going to continue evolving and changing and assumptions that somebody might be having about that system are
going to change really rapidly and so you need to have some involvement with the code to understand how it's
evolving over time at the same time if you're spending as much time as a developer
writing code let's say you're spending 70 or 80 of your time designing and coding you're not taking
care of a whole bunch of responsibilities and probably nobody is going to take care of them as a result
and so there's a lot of things that will sort of be unaddressed uh until it's too late so be until you
have an incident when people haven't really built enough sort of stability or resilience into their code perhaps it's about technical debt where
everything just gets slower and slower over time because people are really frustrated by how hard it is to make new changes
somebody and that somebody is the tech lead needs to make sure that those topics are being addressed and that takes time away from the code
so you'll never spend as much time as you would as a developer because the value you add is
different at the same time you do need to spend some time and you know one of the heuristics is
thinking about this over an average time frame there will be periods where you get pulled away from
the code be it your planning phase or a project initiation phase where you might spend maybe two or three
weeks in lots of meetings it's a very common thing for this role what that's telling you is you need to come back to a balance and say okay i've
spent a lot of time away from the code i need to understand how things have evolved right to understand where that risk lies and
so the next weeks after that you might spend more time with the team in code to understand how
that happens and it doesn't mean you have to write code you can do a lot more code reviews and reading code
to get a sense of how things are evolving as well so how to shift uh you know this idea of
being an individual contributor to being a real technical leader the first thing is awareness which is great because you're all here so you

feedback so find somebody who can give you advice or feedback about how you're actually doing
and then also to make sure you deliberately practice so like you might do code cutters as a developer you also
need to focus on finding opportunities to practice this so you can see yourself uh sort of
improving over time as well now particularly around leadership there are many different skills out there that
you can sort of focus on and there are many great resources around each of these areas
the hard part will be making a choice about where you should invest in to have the most impact and that will be

depending on what you'd actually like to improve on and so you know there's many great business

developing leadership skills in particular so we looked at this story about how people find themselves in this role
we've looked at what is this tech lead let's cover the surprises and struggles and we'll cover in particular
three surprises and struggles that are very common for people on this journey if you've played this role before
hopefully you recognize some of these things if you haven't played this role yet you can prepare yourself to understand what
these are so the first one you might notice is depicted by a lot of people in a corner
and perhaps one person on the side and this is really about the the feeling of loneliness
right so as a tech lead there's typically only one of you on our team and that's very different
from when you were a developer when you have a lot of developers on a team and so you get a sense of this sort of
outsider perspective or you feel like an outsider you know once you were sort of part of that sort of team
suddenly you're feeling outside now if you've been a developer and you've been promoted into a tech lead role
you sort of recognize this because you recognize your relationship with your friends or your peers has changed a
little bit and that's quite natural because it is a different role you'll be involved in different conversations
you'll have access to different information uh that will make you feel a little bit more alone and a natural
part of this role is also trying to work out you know the right level of being the right level of information teams
need to know there can be too much information that you can distract your team so one side you're trying to sort of
protect them from distractions things that are uncertain things that will change so they can focus on getting
things done but at the same time you're also trying to make sure that they have the right context so they can make good decisions
and having access to that making those decisions will simply make you feel lonely so it's just a natural part of
the role and everyone goes through this on this journey the second surprise and
struggle that a lot of people have is depicted by this diagram with lots of different arrows and what i mean by this is dealing with
uncertainty right so one of the hard things for a lot of people moving into this role
is as an engineer we like to have right answers like what's the correct answer right
tell me what's the right solution and the hard thing about leading and
with people is that there's often not a right answer right so sometimes there's a good enough
answer for now based on our information but the information that we have will hopefully change over time as well
and this is kind of hard to kick because as a developer we're used to this kind of binary world right so we have tests
that go red that tell us things are not working and then go green when they tell us things are working we have uh
builds or continuous integration builds that tell us uh you know our system is not working or is working uh you know
you have computers that you know stop working or they turn on so we're used to this kind of binary
world but unfortunately once again when leading people in teams you're making a judgment call
and judgment calls don't necessarily have a right answer they have to balance a number of
different sort of quality is to come up with a good enough answer and that's something that you'll
have to accept when you're moving into something like this role as well um and once again information that you
have is going to be imperfect it takes time to collect information you know be
asking everyone's opinion on a team and by the time that you actually uh you know get to the last person on
the team people that you maybe spoke to first have maybe changed their mind so you're always dealing with imperfect
information which means you can never come up with the perfect answer
so the third surprise and struggle that everyone goes through on this journey is depicted by this snowflake and
perhaps you might understand this is that people are puzzling so people are unique and that's why i've depicted them as a
sort of snowflake here everyone has their different preferences everyone has a different
stage of their life that they're going through people will have different uh maybe communication
preferences about how they'd like to receive information or how much they'd like to be involved
and the myriad of people that you'll deal with will be countless that you know it'll always be very surprising
the great thing about this is you can focus on understanding people's strengths to recognize where people uh can can um uh be where
their strengths can be applied and be useful to your team and it's useful to build passions or archetypes so try not to stereotype
which is pretending how you think somebody is going to react because you don't ever know people are
unique but you might start to recognize some patterns that might prepare you for different scenarios to make sure at
least you cover a majority of perhaps communication preferences or at least recognize how people would like to work
in different styles as well and you'll build up your portfolio of archetypes as you gain more experience
as well so these three surprises and struggles are very common
and you know it is just part of naturally going on this journey as a technical leader my lesson for here for you is taking
comfort that others have already been on this journey so you don't have to be the person who
feels like you might be alone because you have access to other people who've been on this journey before so to address this my best tip for a lot
of people going to this role is building your support structure so if you're in a bigger company you probably have other tech leads
of other teams that you can probably reach out to maybe you have somebody who you've worked with before that you
can reach out to and ask them to mend for you but make sure that you actually have somebody that you can talk to
they won't exactly understand your same circumstance but you'll have a sort of shoulder to cry on
or an ear to bounce ideas off or ideas to sort of ask how they might approach different situations
that will help you deal with these surprises and struggles once again nobody is going to be perfect
everyone will have a different style but it'll help you feel a lot more supported to take care of these surprises and struggles
so we've looked at surprises and struggles let's look at a couple of tips that i think will help you be a really great tech lead
my first tip is really focusing on developing others a lot of people think you know my role as a technical leader is continue to
developing code to work as a developer but you have the best opportunity if you actually
focus on developing your team so that your team has uh better capabilities and a typical way
that a lot of people think about this is falling into this sort of trap of being you know telling people what to
do or delegating immediately and you might notice that this is that sort of binary trap once again
which is a mode of either or and as a leader you'll have to start to break that and so it needs to be a little bit
more refined one of my favorite models for this is the situational leadership model and it talks about in a different
situation you will choose a different mode of leadership right and the goal here is to get to a
point where you can delegate something to other people but one of the fears of complete delegation
is the fear that every sort of developer has is it's never going to be the same quality as what i would produce
and so you don't necessarily go directly to delegation and you don't necessarily say here is exactly how you have to do
things you might need to actually build up that skill and experience so you get comfortable based on that
situation one of the modes in there is that you might need to sell an opportunity to people
right so you probably get this with senior engineers is that you don't need to tell them what to do
because they're competent at you know building systems but you know maybe they don't really want to take care of a particular task
they don't understand how it adds value or how it's an opportunity for them to grow
and so a mode that you might need to take in is actually selling the opportunity for them about helping them see where they can
actually grow and also take on more responsibility as well another mode of leadership here is
perhaps participating uh you know let's say that you have a incident outage super complex
you can't delegate that immediately because maybe you don't know or you don't trust one person to take
care of it because there are so many people involved this is a mode where you probably need to take part with your team to
understand what's causing the incident how to triage this how to restore service immediately
and make sure that you get the mode uh and and grow people but the key part here is really making
sure that you start to continue to shift more responsibility to other people so that you get time back but also they have opportunities to
grow and the situational leadership model talks about three elements to think
about think about their skill right think about their motivation and also think about the urgency
and then depending on that situation you might adopt a different type of interaction mode
the other uh sort of tool that i would offer you is really focusing on diversity and what i mean by this is
focusing on the different strengths that your team has um you know the bcg did an amazing
research a couple of years ago around understanding the role diversity has in strong organizations they actually
looked at six different elements that contributed to innovation revenue so products uh that built new business
effectively and they noticed that uh or their research found that those four of these were correlated so higher levels
of diversity in four of these elements was strongly correlated with uh higher
levels of innovation revenue and this means that it's a really great opportunity because the more diversity
we have the more broadly we can tackle different types of situations and different
problems as the environment changes around us one of my favorite quotes around this
that i love is that nobody is perfect we all have our strengths but because we have our strengths we
also have our gaps or our weaknesses but working as a team nobody is perfect
but a team can be because when you have a whole bunch of people that are working together our gaps in our strengths can overlap
which means the team as a whole can use the strengths of people in the appropriate situations where it makes
sense and other people can sort of take a step back where it's maybe not their strengths or it's their weaknesses so we
don't have to work on developing our weaknesses as long as we're working with people who have complementary strengths
which is one of the reasons why diverse teams and organizations work so well
one of my favorite books around this is the strengthsfinder book it's run by the gallup organization or
published by people from the gallup organization and they ask the question what made people successful in their roles they
catalogued about 34 different strengths and they noticed that people focused on their strengths in order to be
successful in whatever roles they had and partnered or built teams who had complementary strengths
so if you look at uh doing this book you'll sort of get your top five strengths and then recognize perhaps the strengths
that you don't have and seek out people who have different strengths and as a
tech lead what's really useful about this book is having a vocabulary around identifying these traits and
recognizing where they make a lot of sense one of one of the examples from the book is the achiever strength
so you know we need people who can get things done because if we don't have anybody with an achievement strength you
won't really complete things but at the same time one of the other strengths in the book is called strategic
and it's not really great to have a whole team of just achievers because maybe you'll get a lot of things done
but maybe you'll get a lot of the wrong things done so you also need people who have that strategic strength
to make sure it's moving in the right direction that your organization or team is going and so that book gives you a good
vocabulary and a way to have a conversation with your team to identify where your team strengths
collectively are and also perhaps where your gaps are as well
so lesson five is really about making this move from what i call maker to multiplayer mode one of the
biggest challenges for a lot of people going on this journey is this this sort of trap or falling into this
individual contributor mode where i see my value as the things that i have personally produced
and this is really about that individual contributed track or that maker mode and in order to be very successful as a
technical leader you really need to focus on this multiplier mindset right so as you delegate work or as you
grow other people then they're going to grow and your team is going to be able to deal with things a lot more effectively
if you're building and taking advantage of all the diverse strengths in your team your team will be able to do much more than what you possibly can
and if you help each one of those grow then your team as a whole will be much more resilient and much more
competent than what you possibly could have been and so one of the biggest shifts here is
really taking this mindset shift and making a move from maker to multiplayer mode
so we've gone on this uh very quick journey uh today we've had a look at how people fall into this role

recognize that this is a role change it's not more of the same it's not a promotion it's a side step
into a different role which you may not necessarily have the skills for and you need to start developing
enough skills to be well-rounded in leadership and architecture areas
it does require leadership skills which a lot of people when they find themselves in the role for the first time have never focused on

um and recognize that there are many different resources out there be it books training courses the hard question

you
